awd_titl_txt: NSF INCLUDES Planning Grant: Building Networks and Enhancing Diversity in the K-12 STEM Teaching Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF INCLUDES planning grant is funded by NSF Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES), a comprehensive national initiative to enhance U.S. leadership in discoveries and innovations by focusing on diversity, inclusion and broadening participation in STEM at scale. The goal of this planning grant is to explicitly focus on broadening participation in the K-12 STEM teaching workforce, with the theory of action that diversifying the K-12 STEM teaching workforce would in the long term help more students see STEM as accessible to them and then be more likely to choose a STEM degree or career. Currently there is a large demographic discrepancy between students and teachers in K-12 schools.  Studies have highlighted that the diverse teaching workforce benefits not only students of color but all students. Since 2017, the Smithsonian Science Education Center has conducted an annual STEM Diversity Summit, with the goal of building a coalition (built on collective impact) for attracting and retaining a diverse K-12 STEM teaching workforce, in which teams of teachers and administrators representing 83 school districts, schools, and states across the country shared their problems and developed a logic model to attract and retain a diverse K-12 STEM teaching workforce in their region with annual support from a matched mentor. This planning grant supports revisiting those former teams to better understand the dynamics of systems change through close examination of the successes and challenges outlined in their logic models with the perspective of the Cultural-Historical Activity Theory (CHAT). Under the collaborative infrastructure elements of shared vision and partnerships, this planning grant will inform and lay the foundation for a future alliance focused on diversifying the K-12 STEM teaching workforce.

In this planning grant, the Smithsonian in collaboration with Howard University, as well as in partnership with other experts in STEM teacher education, professional development, and diversity - including from Harvard University, Rutgers University, 100kin10, National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, MA Department of Higher Education, STEM Equity Alliance, National Science Teaching Association, and private industry - will work on four primary activities. First, a survey will be developed and conducted with faculty members of Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs), including approximately 100 Minority Serving Institutions, which serve diverse populations in K-12 teacher preparation programs and STEM education across the country.  The goal of the survey is to understand what roles IHEs play in organizational change management and strategic planning to diversify the K-12 STEM teaching workforce. Second, a virtual workshop will be convened to bring former STEM Diversity Summit attendees and their extended networks to reflect on their progress and activities in past years and discuss strategic long-term plans. Third, a survey with the virtual workshop participants will be conducted to better understand their practices, attitudes, and perceptions about their roles to create culturally diverse ecosystems in K-12 STEM education. Finally, all the collected information from the above activities will be used to investigate strategies and evidence-based practices of enhancing diversity in the K-12 STEM teaching workforce, and an iterative source book will be developed based on those findings as an initial resource to ground future work. Over a 12 month period, this planning grant will build a network between the former teams and with the extended partners, including the NSF INCLUDES National Network, and help them to grow as regional hubs within a Future NSF INCLUDES Alliance focused on diversifying the K-12 STEM teacher workforce, with the Smithsonian as the backbone organization. 

This planning grant is also supported by the NSF Discovery Research preK-12 Program, which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering, mathematics and computer science (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of STEM education innovations and approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. student population (children under 18) has become increasingly diverse. In 2014, students of color outnumbered non-Hispanic White students for the first time1; and, it is expected that more than half of the student population will be from one or more minority groups and only 36.4% of students will be White by 20602. On the other hand, the majority (nearly 80%) of the PK-12 teacher population is White and more than 40% of U.S. public schools have no teachers of color at all3. This student-teacher diversity gap is one of the reasons for failure of public schools to provide students of color with opportunities to learn, creating an achievement and retention gap between White students and minority students4,5, and it is expected to persist unless efforts are made to decrease the gap.

In this planning grant, Smithsonian Science Education Center in collaboration with Howard University performed three main tasks to help schools, school districts, state education agencies, and education organizations enhance the diversity of the K-12 STEM teaching workforce. First, we held a 2-day virtual STEM Education Summit Alumni Workshop on July 8th and 9th, 2021, by inviting former participants of 83 teams who had attended the Smithsonian's STEM Education Summit in the years of 2017 - 2020 (Figure 1), where each team made up of teachers, school/district/state administrators, and educators of non-profit education organizations, got together and developed their logic models (action plans) to attract and retain K-12 STEM teachers from diverse populations.

 

Figure 1. Geographic distribution of the teams who had attended the Smithsonian's STEM Education Summit since 2017

 

It was the first time that we recalled the former participants and held the Alumni Workshop in 2021. Nearly 50 educators, including K-12 STEM teachers, school/district administrators, local community partners, and faculty of Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs), attended the Alumni Workshop from 13 different states (Figure 2), and shared their reflections of implementation of action plans, struggles and challenges, and strategies that were used to resolve the challenges.

 

Figure 2. Geographic distribution of the 2021 Alumni Workshop attendees 

 

The participants discussed activity systems and systems change with the perspective of Cultural-Historical Activity Theory (CHAT), identified tensions in their own system, and shared expected roles of individuals in a system (Figure 3). They also had conversations with panelists from 6 different IHEs about the IHEs' perspectives and challenges on pre-service STEM teacher education programs. Throughout the 2-day convening, the participants met others from across the country, built potential partnerships and networks, and developed an overarching shared vision to enhance the diversity of the K-12 STEM teaching workforce.

 

Figure 3. Cultural-Historical Activity Theory: Activity system implementing a logic model 

 

Second, we developed and conducted a survey to better understand what roles IHEs (specifically Minority Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities) may play in organizational change management and strategic planning to diversify the K-12 STEM teaching workforce. Among the approximately 100 IHEs that the survey was sent to, we received responses from nearly 50% of them and found that while the majority of respondents reported that they partner with K-12 schools to help prepare STEM teachers, many have sought innovative partnerships to accomplish the goal, and they struggle to provide quality education while keeping costs low despite resource constraints. The challenges the MSIs identified are shown in Figure 4.

 

Figure 4. Challenges of the IHEs to the diversification of STEM teacher candidates 

 

Lastly, we developed a sourcebook that contains the information that was shared during the Alumni Workshop and some findings from our participant survey and IHE survey. This sourcebook is freely available for any school, school district, state education agency, or educational organization that is looking for guidance or resources about broadening participation and developing a shared vision for diversifying the K-12 STEM teaching workforce. You can find the sourcebook at the Smithsonian Science Education Center's website: https://ssec.si.edu/includes-sourcebook  

Through this project, we learned that IHEs and K-12 education systems have strong commitments to diversifying the K-12 STEM teaching workforce. This goal is achievable through collaborative and innovative partnerships, along with a shared vision for broadening participation in STEM.

References:

1. National Center for Education Statistics. (2019, February). Status and trends in the education of racial and ethnic groups. National Center for Education Statistics. Retrieved from: https://nces.ed.gov/programs/raceindicators/indicator_rbb.asp 

2. Vespa, J., Medina, L., & Armstrong, D. M. (2020). Demographic Turning Points for the United States: Population Projections for 2020 to 2060. Retrieved from: https://www.census.gov/content/dam/Census/library/publications/2020/demo/p25-1144.pdf 

3. National Center for Education Statistics. (2020). Race and Ethnicity of Public School Teachers and Their Students. U.S. Department of Education. Retrieved from: https://nces.ed.gov/pubs2020/2020103/index.asp

4. Cochran-Smith, M. (2004). Walking the road: Race, diversity, and social justice in teacher education. New York: Teachers College Press

5. Haycock, K. (2001). Closing the achievement gap. Educational Leadership, 58(6), 6-11.
